conclusion: We want the instant at which the separation S between the two objects reaches its largest value.
Let Δx(t) ≡ xA(t) − xB(t) be that separation.
Its time-derivative is the relative velocity dΔx / dt = vA(t) − vB(t).
The separation increases while vA > vB, is stationary when vA = vB, and decreases when vA < vB.
On the diagram the two curves have exactly two intersections: at t = 0 (the common start) and at t = t2 (later on).
Between those two instants the straight line for A always lies above the curved line for B.

premise: The straight line for A always lies above the curved line for B between t = 0 and t = t2.
conclusion: vA > vB and dΔx/dt is positive; the separation therefore grows the whole time.

premise: At t = t2 the curves meet again, giving vA = vB.
conclusion: dΔx/dt = 0. That is the first time after the start when the separation stops growing, so it is the moment of maximum distance.

premise: The separation stops growing at t = t2.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at t = t2 (the second intersection of the velocity–time graphs).
